content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Will there be zombies ? gnark gnark.
Ok, good for a clash.
But I suggest you add a testcase with fake '+' signs,
so that we can't only count the + (minus the 4 coins).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun and challenging

Add some tests where a plus doesn't equal to a grave and adjust your solution accordingly. The statement implies there needs to be a | below the + for the grave to count but you don't even check it yourself. What if there's a random cross lying around in the graveyard, because some priest misplaced it? :P

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: this is a fun variation on a simple counting
Instead of looking for your grandfather, look for Arch Stanton's grave, if you understand the reference. ;-)
Having a grave not just be a + can make for a fun challenge if there are +'s in the graveyard that don't have a | beneath.

For all these cases, it seems that all a solver would need to do is count the "+".  Subtract 4 from that total (i.e., subtract out the corners).  
(Then put that number under 1 to get the percentage.)

In other words, you could pass this Clash by writing code that would count this as a grave

+
=

or

{+}

or

+
(with nothing under it)

I would suggest putting cases (test and validator) in with something like the above examples in the graveyard, to make sure the code doesn't count them as graves.

I was trying to golf it in python and I found this (I'm not even sure why it works lol)

#n=open(0).read().count("+")-4or print("0%")
#print(f'{100/n:.0f}%')

and the finally a bit shorter, making use of the rounding:
#n=open(0).read().count("+")-4or 999
#print(f'{100/n:.0f}%')

Fun clash! I'll suggest to add  in the statement the fact that you have to round the result (I know that it's on the output description but yeah, for clarity sake)

Please explain a bit more about the string representation of a graveyard, and how the chance should be calculated (in words at least if not providing a formula, e.g. 1-in-x chance where there are x graves).
Added info about the representation. Also, I wasn't sure if it was really needed to give more info about the chance calculation, but I added something anyways

This only works because all testcases contain exactly 4 plus signs in addition to any graves (there are no plus signs without a pipe symbol underneath them except for the lower corners).
If there were any "invalid" graves, your code wouldnt work :)
Shortened code:
# print(f'{100/(open(0).read().count("+")-4or 999):.0f}%')
Yes, definitely. Please add test cases with "only +" and "| above +" as robustness check.

Ah I thought about your solution but in my mind they were of same length oops, thanks! 

When I said I wasn't sure why it worked I meant that in this code:
#n=open(0).read().count("+")-4or print("0%")
#print(f'{100/n:.0f}%')
when there are no graves in the rectangle, the program prints 0% and then what the hell happens in the second line???  It prints a print? Here's the what the codingame IDE says:
#TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for /: 'int' #and 'NoneType'
#at Answer.py. in <module> on line 2

So I guess it prints the 0% and then it shuts down because it bugs (I guess the print is NoneType in python?), but the IDE doesn't care since you already outputted the required 0% ??
Correct - since you already wrote something in the output, it doesn't care about any errors (it never does - the only important thing is what's written to the output).
Thank you. A well-defined puzzle is better when the mode is not Reverse.

From the first picture I didn't grasp the representation. Maybe you can show a bigger graveyard with only one or two graves (and mention this meaning in the explanation next to it!)?

The solution is not robust against fake graves (which should be tested, as I mentioned above)! If you don't test it (which is understandable, due to the 5-minute-limit), there is no point in requesting the "bar below cross" in the specs. You may remove it and concentrate on the percentage.

Also a "shifted graveyard" test case (spaces at the left or top) might add some spice to the puzzle.

Nice idea otherwise.
